awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Testing Laurentide Ice Sheet Climate Response and Younger Dryas Trigger with Glacial Varves
awd_abstract_narration:
This project has two objectives. 1) Document the response of the former ice sheet that covered the North American mid-continent to rapid climate changes that occurred at the end of the last ice age. Such a record enhances our ability to predict the response of ice sheets to modern climate change. 2) Test the role of increased freshwater influx to the Atlantic Ocean as a possible trigger for these rapid climate changes, specifically the cold interval known as the Younger Dryas. Modern freshening in the North Atlantic and Arctic Oceans has raised concerns that global warming driven increases in glacier runoff could trigger climate cooling. To evaluate models that use this event to assess the future response of the Atlantic Ocean to predicted freshening, the connections (if any) between freshwater discharge and routing before and during the Younger Dryas need to be resolved.

The primary records that will be generated are varve thickness datasets from a large glacial lake, proximal to the former ice sheet. Glacial varves are yearly sediment couplets that appear similar to tree rings, and as such provide an annually resolvable record of how climate affected the ice sheet. The varves will be recovered by coring sediments from many lakes, spanning a broad region west of Lake Superior. By matching thickness patterns between all sites, a 5000+ year time series is anticipated. Working in collaboration with staff at Voyageurs National Park (Minnesota), this work will be showcased for the general public via a permanent indoor exhibit on varves as records of climate and environmental change.

por.por_cntn:
Predicting the response of the Greenland and Antarctica ice sheets to our changing climate is a scientific challenge of our time. Understanding the response of the former ice sheets in North America to warming could serve as a modern analogue. With this goal in mind, this project developed a 3,500-year sediment record of ice sheet behavior at the end of the Pleistocene, a period characterized by extreme shifts in global climate (both warming and cooling) known as the Bolling-Allerod and Younger Dryas. The sediments are varves, annual couplets of silt and clay deposited in glacial lakes, which appear similar to tree rings. These varves are from Lake Agassiz, the largest of all the glacial lakes that rimmed the former ice sheet. This new varve series is the first of its kind in North America for this dynamic period. 

This project accomplished two objectives: 1) The varves document increasing rates of ice retreat during the Bolling-Allerod warming, followed by a re-advance and slower retreat during the Younger Dryas cool period. These ice sheet responses to climate change are not unexpected, but the ice margin responses are delayed by hundreds of years, which is surprising. These varves should help test models of paleo-ice sheet behavior, and provide high-resolution calibration data sets useful for predicting ice-sheet response in our modern, warming world. 2) The varves also provide a test of a hypothesis that freshwater discharge from Lake Agassiz to the Atlantic Ocean triggered the Younger Dryas cold interval. Modern freshening in the North Atlantic and Arctic Oceans has raised concerns that global warming-driven increases in glacier runoff could cause climatic cooling. To evaluate models that use this event to assess the future response of the Atlantic Ocean to predicted freshening, the connections between freshwater discharge and routing before and during the Younger Dryas need resolved. Our results suggest that Lake Agassiz freshwater did not trigger the Younger Dryas cooling because the timing of the lake drainage postdates the onset of the Younger Dryas by hundreds of years.

The project also provided impactful experiential learning opportunities for 30 undergraduate students at the University of Wisconsin-Superior through multiple mechanisms, including special projects courses, many field and lab activities in standard courses, research assistantships, and independent capstone projects. Physical samples of correlated varves from Voyageur's National Park have also been prepared in order to create a display at the park visitor center that will educate visitors about how these sediments, hidden below the modern lakes, record climate and environmental changes of the past.
